snippet: The particles, which are known as black carbon and are the major component of soot, are the second most important contributor to global warming, according to the recent study.
abstract: Study published in The Journal of Geophysical Research-Atmospheres shows that tiny black particles released into atmosphere by burning fuels, known as black carbon, are second most important contributor to global warming behind carbon dioxide; new estimate of particles' heat-trapping power is double that of 2007 report by United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change; finding adds urgency to effort to curb production of black carbon.
lead_paragraph: The particles, which are known as black carbon and are the major component of soot, are the second most important contributor to global warming, according to the recent study.

headline.seo: Burning Fuel Particles Do More Damage to Climate Than Thought, Study Says
headline.main: Burning Fuel Particles Do More Damage to Climate Than Thought, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Burning Fuel Particles Do More Damage To Climate Than Thought, Study Says
